To roll up a flag; it can also mean to wrap a sail tightly around a pole
To catch fly balls in baseball practice
Put a vowel before a word for a secret agent & you get this verb meaning "catch sight of"
From the Latin for "praise", it means to praise or glorify as in a hymn
In 2024 this university in Durham, North Carolina celebrated its centennial
In the early 17th c. plans to build this Virginia school were disrupted by the Powhatan uprising; it wasn't founded until 1693
Called one of the first HBCUs, Storer College was in this town, the site of a failed 1859 revolt
This university was founded in Philadelphia, after "night owls" studied in founder Russell Conwell's church
Chartered in 1901, this college in Southern California was named for a Quaker poet
"Maidenform" & "Guy Walks into an Advertising Agency" were episodes of this Emmy-winning drama
Rowan Atkinson starred in 4 BBC alternate history comedy series as title characters with this colorfully reptilian name
The evil Dr. Claw is the perennial foe of this bumbling animated detective
From 2014 to 2019 TÃ©a Leoni starred as State Department Chief Elizabeth McCord, addressed by this title title
As the title indicated, Mr. Conover wrecked stuff as the host & title character of this investigative comedy series
Before the White House, when his house overlooking Santa Monica Bay was built in 1956, GE outfitted it with energy-saving tech
He used profits from selling the Texas Rangers (ballplayers, not lawmen) to buy Prairie Chapel Ranch in McLennan County
In 1823 Andrew Jackson donated land from this home to build a house of worship called Ephesus Church
Sherwood Forest, John Tyler's home, was owned in the late 18th century by this immediate predecessor
Mrs. Hoover designed a Lou & Herb-arium on this college's campus; the home was deeded to the school upon her death
It's a solid bet to say this all-time hit king hustled home with the trophy for the Reds in 1975
In 1963 & again in 1965, Sandy Koufax brought the heat & took home the hardware for this team

clues.text: As a verb this piece of car talk means to choke or strangle someone
Adjective for things in the order they happened, like a list of an author's works in publication sequence
It's from the Greek for "love of humankind"; an old definition also meant the love of god for humanity
This type of coal that contains more than 80% carbon generally has the highest heating value
This thin sheet of muscle below the lungs is unique to mammals
In this 2023 film old man Paul Giamatti & young man Dominic Sessa check out the 1970 Dustin Hoffman film "Little Big Man"
In a 2009 film Johnny Depp as this 1930s gangster watches "Manhattan Melodrama" at the Biograph before meeting his fate
In this 2019 film Margot Robbie as Sharon Tate puts her feet up as she watches herself in a movie at a theater
In "The Shawshank Redemption", Andy DuFresne & Red watch this actress' hair flip scene in "Gilda"
In the film "Divorce Italian Style", scandal comes to a small town when a theater shows this sweetly named 1960 Fellini film
Philip Larkin's "This Be the Verse" says, "They fill you with the faults they had & add some extra, just for you"
A sick kid has "two pillows at my head" in Stevenson's "Land of Counter-Pane"; a counterpane is this word with 2 rhyming syllables
In 1920 his first poem to make a big splash mentioned Buffalo Bill & Jesus, with capital Bs & a capital J
His "The Runaway" is not even his most famous poem with a horse in falling snow
Though it's often printed broken into short lines, his "No man is an island" is a prose passage; "Air & Angels", that's a poem
In 2014 the Coast Guard gave Norwegian-American WWII vet Andrew Haines the funeral at sea named for these Norsemen
In the Indian city of Varanasi, bodies are cremated near steps that lead into this sacred river
In 2024 remains of this "2001" writer were placed on a spacecraft bound for the Moon; sadly, they never reached that final frontier
At jazz funerals in New Orleans, this ordinal phrase refers to the mourners that trail behind the casket, family & musicians
This pre-Islamic religion of India & Iran still lays their dead on "towers of silence" to be eaten by birds of prey
A 1956 article on the renaming of a car factory said it was the first "major Soviet enterprise" to get rid of this man's name
Akhenaten, the father of this boy pharaoh, was scratched from the history papyrus, likely for his monotheistic beliefs
This author wrote a letter asking a friend to burn all of his unpublished work, like "The Trial" & "The Castle"
After Herostratus burned down this edifice in Ephesus it's no "wonder" the townsfolk banned mentioning his name
The Nazis tried to destroy copies of a propaganda film by this female director since it heavily featured a supposed Nazi traitor
At the age of 15 this creator of Flopsy & Mopsy began keeping a journal in a secret code she invented
On Sept. 2, 1666 Samuel Pepys walked to this prison fortress & "got up upon one of the high places" to watch his city burn
